description: NPR's Ailsa Chang speaks with soccer writer Dermot Corrigan about the latest action at the men's Euro Cup 2024.
title: Some of the best men's soccer teams collide at the UEFA European Championship

description: Experts are struggling to prepare vulnerable communities for potential wildfire catastrophes. One new approach is a community-wide board game that tests resilience and preparedness.
title: This board game may help communities prepare for wildfire catastrophes

description: Ten years after staging an armed standoff with federal agents on his Nevada ranch, Cliven Bundy remains free. As does his son Ammon, despite an active warrant for Ammon from Idaho related to a harassment lawsuit.
title: A decade after armed standoff, the Bundys appear to be above the law

description: Social Security's SSI program for people with disabilities requires couples to have no more than $3,000 in assets
title: Couples say they can't get married because of this government program's outdated rules.

description: In Thailand, lawmakers have voted overwhelmingly to legalize same-sex marriage. If the measure goes into effect, Thailand’s government would become only the third in Asia to permit same-sex marriage.
title: In a win for Thailand's LGBTQ community, lawmakers vote to legalize same-sex marriage

description: Hurricane Maria, which tore through Puerto Rico in 2017, also devastated a tiny nearby island that's home to hundreds of monkeys. All that destruction seems to have transformed the monkeys' society.
title: How Hurricane Maria transformed a society of macaques

description:
A growing number of children in the U.S. are being targeted in sextortion schemes— a scam in which a cybercriminal obtains and then threatens to release nude or sexually compromising photos, blackmailing victims for a ransom. And sadly dozens of young victims have died by suicide in the last few years. Cybercriminals are often based abroad and it is a particular problem in Nigeria. Our correspondent in Lagos, Nigeria tells us about the issue, about the tragic case of one 17 year-old victim who took his own life, and about what the FBI is doing to combat the problem.

If you or someone you know may be considering suicide or is in crisis, please get support. In the U.S. you can call or text 988 to reach the Suicide & Crisis Lifeline.
title: The International Problem of Online Sextortion

description: NPR's Ailsa Chang speaks with journalist Stephen Witt about chip-maker Nvidia's rise to become the most valuable company in the world and what it means for the future of AI.
title: What does Nvidia's meteoric rise indicate about AI's potential?

description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks with Aaron Mackey with the Electronic Frontier Foundation — a nonprofit which advocates for civil liberties in the digital world — about warning labels on social media.
title: Surgeon General's call for labels on social media is 'fearmongering,' say opponents

description: The actor appeared in hundreds of films and shows, including M*A*S*H, Klute, Ordinary People and the Hunger Games franchise. He was best known for playing off-kilter authority figures.
title: Donald Sutherland, a subtle and sardonic star, has died at 88

description: Median home prices were about five times the median income last year, according to a Harvard report, and it could get worse. And centuries-old cherries were discovered at George Washington’s home.
title: U.S. prices far outpace paychecks; centuries-old fruit found at Washington’s home

description: Former President Donald Trump loves acronyms, but his sayings have become increasingly varied. NPR analyzes six of Trump’s most common catchphrases on the campaign trail in 2024.
title: 6 things Trump says at his rallies and what they really mean

description: Russia has accelerated its destruction of Ukraine's front-line cities in 2024 to a scale previously unseen in the war using glide bombs and an expanding network of airstrips just across the border.
title: Russia wages a scorched-earth war in Ukraine with retrofitted bombs and new airstrips

description: NPR's Michel Martin talks to marketing expert Professor Marcus Collins about how organizations decide whether to speak out on prominent social issues.
title: How organizations decide whether to take a stand on social issues

description: A plant was rediscovered by accident in Vermont last month, the first time it was seen in more than a century.
title: Botanists in Vermont rediscovered a plant last seen there at the start of WW1

description: People without easy access to capital are getting into housing development in Philadelphia, as part of a program designed to create more affordable housing and boost non-traditional developers.
title: Philadelphia aims to create a pipeline of affordable housing developers with access to capital

description: The Biden administration's student loan relief program, SAVE, is set to reduce payments this summer for many borrowers, but there are legal challenges looming.
title: 3 things you need to know about student loans this summer

description: Archaeologists unearthed 35 bottles of cherries from the cellar of George Washington's Mount Vernon. The 250-year-old fruits, many still intact, can shed new light on those who lived and worked there.
title: Centuries-old cherries were found at George Washington's home. What can they tell us?

description: Suffering stomach pain, a Dallas man visited his local urgent care clinic — or so he thought, until he got a bill 10 times what he’d expected.
title: It’s called an urgent care emergency center — but which is it?

description: Women comprise more than half of medical school graduates, but the number of female surgeons is low. A club at a Kansas medical school offers them support and mentorship.
title: Kansas doctors say mentorship can help as women are still underrepresented in surgery

description: Russia and North Korea have signed a new treaty upgrading their relationship and pledging military assistance in case either one is attacked.
title: Leaders of Russia and North Korea sign pact -- indicating a deeper cooperation

description: The Israeli military says it is approved an offensive in Lebanon if diplomatic efforts fail to stop the conflict that’s contained, for the most part, in Israel’s north and Lebanon’s south for now.
title: Israel and Lebanese militia Hezbollah are ratcheting up the firepower on the border

description: Sanctions are to be announced against those involved in fentanyl trafficking. Israel and Lebanese militia Hezbollah ratchet up firepower on the border. Cybercriminals target children with sextortion.
title: Morning news brief

description: Surgeon General Vivek Murthy wants tobacco-style warning labels for social media. NPR's Leila Fadel talks to clinical psychologist Michaeline Jensen, who has studied social media's effect on kids.
title: Does science back up the surgeon general's call for a warning label on social media?

description: A secret recording reveals how national groups, such as Moms for Liberty, continue attempting to change American education -- one local school board at a time
title: Recording reveals outside interest in attempts to recall Colo. school board member

description: The U.S. is hosting the Copa América, and the competition has expanded to include North American and Caribbean teams. NPR's Michel Martin talks to soccer writer Jon Arnold.
title: The Copa América soccer tournament kicks off in Atlanta

description: Water utilities and chemical companies are mounting legal challenges to the Environmental Protection Agency's recent rule putting limits on six “forever chemicals” in drinking water.
title: EPA rule limiting certain 'forever chemicals' in drinking water is challenged

description:
Taylor Tomlinson has found the kind of success many comedians dream about, with multiple Netflix specials and a late-night hosting gig — After Midnight on CBS. She tells Rachel that part of the secret to her success is fear. They also swap stories about their Christian upbringings, the search for validation and getting things stuck up their noses.

To listen sponsor-free, access bonus episodes and support the show, sign up for Wild Card+ at plus.npr.org/wildcard
title: How Taylor Tomlinson learned to embrace her 'constant hum of fear'

description: In nearly half of metro areas, buyers must make more than $100,000 to afford a median-priced home, a Harvard University report finds. And home prices this year reached a new all-time high.
title: U.S. home prices have far outpaced paychecks. See what it looks like where you live

description: The group Just Stop Oil took credit for the Wednesday afternoon action, which they said was a call on the United Kingdom to stop the use of fossil fuels by 2030.
title: 2 climate activists were arrested after spraying orange paint on Stonehenge
